Package me.wobblyyyy.pathfinder.recording

Class RecorderNormal

  • java.lang.Object
    • me.wobblyyyy.pathfinder.recording.RecorderNormal
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    RecorderInterface
    public class RecorderNormal
extends java.lang.Object
implements RecorderInterface
    An implementation of the Recorder code provided in this library.

    Rather than using the raw Recorder, you're probably going to have a better time just using this class. Using this shouldn't exactly be too difficult, you're just going to have to make sure to read all of the JavaDocs here. I promise, reading some documentation will help. It's crazy, I know, but it works.

    Author:
    Colin Robertson

      • rw

        private PfRwNormal rw

    • Method Detail

      • startRecording

        public void startRecording​(long duration,
                           long delay,
                           long interval)
        Start a new recording. Keep in mind - this will override any loaded recording.
        Specified by:
        startRecording in interface RecorderInterface
        Parameters:
        duration - the duration of the recording. I don't really want to type out all of my reasoning behind this, but I would suggest that you try to keep the duration of the recordings to about 10 seconds. 10 seconds as a max, that is. Shorter recordings don't have any performance issues, but the longer the recording is - and thus the more memory it takes up - the worse the performance will be.
        delay - how long before the recording starts. This is really only useful if you're trying to record during an OpMode - say, for example, you want to record, but want to have a couple seconds of prep.
        interval - how long between times the motor power of the robot is logged. Once again, I'm just going to ask you to trust me on this one. Keep this to a minimum of about 50ms. 100ms, even, would have very little impact on the operation of the robot. Performance will shrink (and you may encounter crashes) if you make this value too low or too high. 50ms is optimal for 10s recordings.

      • executeRecording

        public void executeRecording()
        Execute the loaded recording.

        Obviously, you can't run this before you actually either create or load a recording to use.

        Specified by:
        executeRecording in interface RecorderInterface

      • update

        public void update​(PfMotorPower motorPower)
        Update the motorPower of the recording. For your own good, you should really strongly consider reading the rest of this documentation.

        This should be updated as frequently as possible without encountering any potential performance downsides. Updating the motorPower every single ms is obviously optimal - you'll get extremely accurate positional data on the robot, and, as a result, the recording will function most optimally.

        You also have to keep something in mind here - every single recorded instance of power given to the motors takes up a bit of a couple of things...

        • File space. Large files take longer to read and write.
        • Memory. Large files require more memory.
        • Performance. Less memory means less potential performance.
        • A LOT of asynchronous events. Based on some of my previous experimentation with the async functionality of this library, instances of StringEvents can typically have up to 300 or so handles before performance begins to take a serious hit.

        Specified by:
        update in interface RecorderInterface
        Parameters:
        motorPower - the power the motors are currently receiving.
